title: Pressure density column and single fluid

content.question: Cylinders <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> are identical hollow containers. Equal volumes of five different liquids, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>, <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>D</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>E</mtext></math>, are poured into Cylinder <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The liquids separate, forming five distinct layers, as shown in the figure. Cylinder <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is filled with the same total volume of liquid as Cylinder <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, but with only liquid <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>. A student claims the pressure at the bottom of Cylinder <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> must be equal to the pressure at the bottom of Cylinder <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Is the studentâ€™s claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the total depth of liquid in each cylinder is the same.
Yes, because the total depth of liquid and the average density of the liquid in each cylinder is the same.

No, because the pressure at the bottom of Cylinder <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> must be greater than the pressure at the bottom of Cylinder <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> because Cylinder <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> contains some liquid that is more dense than the liquid in Cylinder <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.
No, because the pressure at the bottom of the two columns of liquid cannot be compared without knowing the relative values of the densities of the individual fluids.

content.answer: No, because the pressure at the bottom of the two columns of liquid cannot be compared without knowing the relative values of the densities of the individual fluids.
